isis.stitle: TSI 08-04-01 - Full Power Brakes SAHR System Troubleshooting

subjectgroup.subject: Full Power Brakes SAHR System Troubleshooting

geninfo.para: The purpose of this document is to provide detailed troubleshooting information for the Spring Assist Hydraulic Release (SAHR) Parking Brake system used in the Full Power Brakes System. This information is to be used in conjunction with the Full Power Brakes service manual, and the TOOLBOX™ diagnostic program.

note.para: It is assumed that Vehicle Recall G-06504 has been performed on the vehicle under test, if the vehicle is covered by that recall.

svcproc.title: Service procedure

warning.para: To avoid personal injury or death, shift transmission to neutral or park, set parking brake, and block wheels before doing diagnostic or service procedures.

svcproc.para: Troubleshooting the Full Power Brakes System begins with reviewing any brake related Diagnostic Trouble Codes (DTC's), using the TOOLBOX™ diagnostic program. While the TOOLBOX™ program provides adequate repair instructions for most DTC's, the following SAHR related DTC's may require the supplemental information provided in this document. The procedures in this document assume that the SERVICE PARK BRAKE indicator is lit and ALL other brake related DTC's have been resolved.
This document covers the following Park Brake DTC's, as displayed in TOOLBOX™:

item.para: 61 3 Travel Switch output implausible, (or could not be applied)

When the park brake is commanded to apply, the travel switch has indicated to the ECU that the SAHR shaft has remained in the released position. The ECU sends a message to the Gauge Cluster to turn on the SERVICE PARK BRAKE indicator; and may operate the park brake system in the Backup Mode.
Possible causes:
Travel Switch (or wiring)
Electronic Control Unit (ECU)
SAHR canister mechanical malfunction
Cut-off valve (SAHR cartridge)
Pressure Supply Valve (PSV)
Driveline park brake components binding or broken
Park brake cable binding
61 4 Park Brake could not be released,

When the park brake is commanded to release, the travel switch has indicated to the ECU that the SAHR shaft has remained in the applied position. This code may also indicate that after extending to the released position, the SAHR shaft repeatedly retracted enough to require 'replenishment' of the brake fluid in the SAHR canister. In either case, the ECU operates the park brake system in the Backup Mode; and sends a message to the Gauge Cluster to turn on the SERVICE PARK BRAKE indicator.
Possible causes:
Travel Switch (or wiring)
Electronic Control Unit (ECU)
SAHR canister mechanical malfunction (binding)
Cut-off valve (SAHR cartridge). NOTE: Cut-off valve COIL faults are covered by separate DTC's, which must be resolved before performing these procedures.
PSV. NOTE: PSV COIL faults are covered by separate DTC's, which must be resolved before performing these procedures.
61 13 SAHR shaft overtravel.

During park brake application, the travel switch has indicated to the ECU that the SAHR shaft has retracted further than the specified limit. The SAHR shaft dimension is [lt ]8.1 inches. The ECU operates the park brake system in the Backup Mode; and sends a message to the Gauge Cluster to turn on the SERVICE PARK BRAKE indicator. NOTE: This condition generally indicates a worn or broken park brake component, not a SAHR assembly problem.
Possible causes:
park brake cable broken, stretched or misadjusted
driveline park brake linings out of adjustment
driveline park brake components worn or broken

warning.para: To prevent unexpected movement of the vehicle and possible serious personal injury or death, block the wheels to prevent the vehicle from moving in both directions.
The full power brake system is a pressurized system that achieves pressures of up to 2320 psi. This pressure IS NOT reduced by switching the ignition off or removing battery power.

Prior to removing components from this system, the depressurization procedures in the service manual MUST BE PERFORMED EXACTLY AS PRESENTED. Since it is assumed that a component has failed, you should assume that trapped, pressurized fluid may be present whenever a component is removed. Remove components from the fluid system cautiously.
Refer to the appropriate service manual in ISIS before removing any components. Failure to depressurize the system may result in property damage, personal injury or death.

entry.para: Step
Procedure
Test Point
Yes, Meets Spec
No, Does Not Meet Spec
Chock tires, place transmission in a Neutral position, connect EZ-Tech, turn key to ON.
To establish a known condition, attempt to apply the park brake using the dash Park Brake switch.
NOTE: Do not place transmission in a P or PB position, as this may not allow proper testing of the Park Brake system.
Go to next step.
Go to next step.
Using TOOLBOX, verify that only one or more of the following brake related DTC's have been logged:
Gauge Cluster and TOOLBOX
Go to next step.
If other brake related codes are set, resolve them using TOOLBOX before troubleshooting the SAHR system with these procedures.
Record the brake related DTC's, then using TOOLBOX, clear all inactive DTC's.
TOOLBOX
Go to next step.
Go to next step.
Use the COMPONENT TEST menu within TOOLBOX to release the PB (Park Brake), if possible.
Continue procedure regardless of PB status.
TOOLBOX
Go to next step.
Go to next step.
Inspect PB cables and cable clamps/guides. Verify cables are connected and not kinked or bound.
PB cables and cable clamps/ guides
Go to next step.
Make any necessary repairs.
Verify that there is no indication of brake fluid leakage on the SAHR canister (near vent hole) and PB line.
SAHR canister and fittings on PB line.
Go to next step.
If a leak is evident, make the necessary repairs.
Replace cut-off valve/ cartridge/ manifold, fitting, or brake line. Refer to the appropriate service manual on ISIS.

While holding the SAHR shaft with a wrench, back the locknut off enough to check for the indicator stripe on the threaded shaft (Figure 1). The threaded shaft should be adjusted so that the indicator stripe, 'hash mark', is positioned at the end of the SAHR shaft. Adjust the threaded shaft, if necessary; then tighten the locknut.
SAHR canister shaft
Go to next step.
Adjust the threaded shaft, then tighten the locknut.
Check PB operation. If adjustment did not correct operation, continue this procedure.

While observing the SAHR canister shaft, have someone use the COMPONENT TEST menu within TOOLBOX to apply and release the PB several times. Verify that the shaft extends AND retracts when actuated. The amount of shaft travel is not critical in this step.
SAHR canister shaft
Leave PB released (shaft extended), then go to next step.
Go to step 18.
(SAHR canister shaft not responding)

With the PB released, verify that the SAHR canister 'release dimension' measures 10.6 inches (Figure 2). This dimension is measured from the end of the shaft (not including lock nut) to the SAHR canister seam at the vent hole. This dimension is determined by mechanical stops.
SAHR canister shaft
Go to next step.
NOTE: If shaft extends to proper length, go to next step; even if shaft does not remain fully extended.
There is an internal mechanical problem within the SAHR canister and it must be replaced. Refer to the appropriate service manual on ISIS.
Using TOOLBOX apply the PB and verify that the SAHR canister 'apply dimension' measures 8.1 to 9.8 inches.
Like above, this dimension is measured from the end of the shaft to the SAHR canister seam at the vent hole (Figure 2).
In the applied position, this dimension is determined by the following PB system components: SAHR canister, PB cables, PB shoe linings, and PB drum.
SAHR canister shaft
Go to next step.
NOTE: Preferred 'apply dimension' is 8.7 to 9.8 inches. If shaft dimension is between 8.1 and 8.7 inches it indicates PB shoes are out of adjustment, or cable is stretched. Repair as necessary.
Normally, the SERVICE PARK BRAKE light will not indicate an overstroke condition until measurement is [lt ]8.1 inches.
Go to step 17.
(SAHR is UNDER- STROKING or OVERSTROKING during APPLY)
Using TOOLBOX apply the park brake.
Using TOOLBOX clear all brake DTC's.
Cycle the IGN key OFF and back ON.
Verify that the SERVICE PARK BRAKE indicator is unlit.
SERVICE PARK BRAKE indicator is unlit in gauge cluster.
Go to next step.
Go to step 15.
IMPORTANT: This step must be performed the first time the PB is released after clearing the DTC's. The SERVICE PARK BRAKE light must be off. If the light is on, repeat the previous step.
While observing the SAHR canister shaft, have someone use TOOLBOX to release park brake. Observe the SAHR canister shaft for one minute.
The shaft should fully extend and remain extended.
If the shaft retracts slightly, then re-extends 2 to 5 times* AND the SERVICE PARK BRAKE indicator lights (system has entered the 'Backup Mode'); go to step 16.
* The number of replenishments allowed before entering the Backup Mode depends on the ECU software version.
SAHR canister shaft
Go to next step.
Go to step 16.
Verify that the SERVICE PARK BRAKE indicator is unlit.
SERVICE PARK BRAKE indicator.
Go to next step.
Replace the travel sensor.
Refer to the appropriate service manual on ISIS.
Using TOOLBOX apply the park brake.
Verify that the SERVICE PARK BRAKE indicator is unlit.
SERVICE PARK BRAKE indicator.
System currently operating correctly. Fault is intermittent.
Refer to Possible Intermittent Problems and their Causes (after table).
Replace the travel sensor.
Refer to the appropriate service manual on ISIS.
1. Disconnect the travel sensor electrical connector near the SAHR canister.
2. Verify key is ON. Do not start engine.
3. With a multimeter check the pins on the connector from the chassis harness (Figure 3).

item.para: Pin A - 12 to 14 Vdc
Pin B - Continuity to Chassis Ground
Pin C - 12 to 14 Vdc

entry.para: NOTE: Verify that pins of both connectors are tight and free of corrosion. If not, repair or clean connection, then retest.
Chassis harness connector for travel sensor.
Verify that pins of the ECU 31 pin connector are tight and free of corrosion. If not, repair or clean connection, then retest.
If ECU connector is ok, replace the travel sensor.
If problem still exists, replace ECU.
Refer to the appropriate service manual on ISIS.
Isolate faulty circuit between harness connector and ECU, using the appropriate circuit diagram manual, or electrical troubleshooting guide, on ISIS.
Disconnect the electrical connector from the cut-off valve coil. Using a multimeter, measure the resistance of the cut-off valve coil at the pins on the coil connector.

Resistance of the originally installed coils varies by vehicle build date. Replacement parts may also have a different value. Inspect the coil body for a printed resistance value. Typically, the following values can be used:
Vehicles built prior to April 2008: 8.37 to 10.23 Ohms.
Vehicles built April 2008 and after: 6.38 to 8.14 Ohms.
NOTE: Verify that pins of both connectors are tight and free of corrosion. If not, repair or clean connection, then retest.
Cut-off valve electrical connector
Replace cut-off valve/ cartridge/ manifold. Refer to the appropriate service manual on ISIS.
Replace cut-off valve electrical coil. Refer to the appropriate service manual on ISIS.
CAUTION -The maximum torque on the coil retaining nut is CRITICAL.Torque value is 4 to 5 lbf-ft (44 to 60 lbf-in) maximum.
Verify that the SAHR canister 'apply dimension' is [lt ]8.1 inches (Overstroke condition).
SAHR canister shaft
Overstroke.
• Adjust park brake shoes (Refer to service manual s04044).
• If problem still exists, check for broken driveline park brake components or stretched park brake cable(s).
Understroke
Possible causes, correct as necessary:
• Park brake shoes adjusted too tight to drum. (Refer to service manual s04044).
• Binding cable.
• Binding or broken driveline park brake components (shoes, etc.). Refer to service manual s04044
• SAHR canister malfunctioning (springs, binding, etc.). Replace SAHR canister. Refer to the appropriate service manual on ISIS.

caution.para: During some of the following steps, the presence of brake fluid under extreme pressure will be checked. When loosening the bleeder fitting always assume that the brake fluid is pressurized, until proven otherwise. Open the bleeder fitting slowly, and only enough to determine if pressure is present.
During these steps, insure that the hose is securely fastened onto the bleeder fitting and that the entire hose is controlled to prevent 'whipping'.

entry.para: SECURELY connect a hose to the SAHR canister bleeder fitting. Regardless of shaft position, attempt to apply the park brake using TOOLBOX.
Carefully, open the bleeder screw just enough to determine that the brake fluid in the line is NOT PRESSURIZED at this time. Tighten the fitting.
SAHR canister bleeder fitting
Go to next step.
If pressurized fluid was present, replace the Pressure Supply Valve Core. Refer to the appropriate service manual on ISIS.
Read this entire step before proceeding.
NOTE: The TOOLBOX selection used in this step will only energize the PSV for a brief period of time, then de-energize it.
With a hose SECURELY connected to the SAHR canister bleeder fitting, carefully, open the SAHR bleeder screw just enough to monitor the brake fluid pressure in the line.
While monitoring the brake fluid pressure at the bleeder hose, have someone use the following TOOLBOX menus to energize the PSV (Supply Valve): COMPONENT TESTS/ MISCELLANEOUS OUTPUTS.
Verify that the fluid IS PRESSURIZED while the PSV is energized.
Tighten the bleeder fitting, and apply the PB to insure that pressure is released from the brake line.
SAHR canister bleeder fitting
SAHR canister is inoperable.
Possible causes:
• Cut-Off valve is stuck closed, preventing fluid from entering or leaving the SAHR canister. Replace the cut-off valve/ cartridge/ manifold assembly.
• A broken or binding component in the SAHR canister is preventing any movement of the shaft. Replace SAHR canister.
Refer to the appropriate service manual on ISIS.
CAUTION: It may be necessary to disassemble the canister to determine the faulty component. Remove components slowly to prevent injury from trapped pressurized fluid, if present.
If pressurized fluid is NOT present, go to next step.
Disconnect the electrical connector from the Pressure Supply Valve coil.
Using a multimeter, measure the resistance of the Pressure Supply Valve coil at the pins on the coil connector.
Coil resistance must be 10.8 to 13.2 Ohms.
Pressure Supply Valve electrical connector
Replace Pressure Supply Valve. Refer to the appropriate service manual on ISIS.
CAUTION: Do not over-tighten the coil retaining nut.
Replace Pressure Supply Valve electrical coil only. Refer to the appropriate service manual on ISIS.
CAUTION: Do not over-tighten the coil retaining nut.

para.emph: Possible Intermittent Problems and Probable Causes

item.para: Intermittent failure to release. (SAHR shaft has difficulty extending or occasionally will not extend.) Possible Cause(s):
Binding in SAHR canister (Test while SAHR is working correctly.)
Vehicle in Neutral. Key ON. PB applied.
Pull FPB motor fuses (see service manual).
Monitor accumulator pressure with TOOLBOX.
Pump pedal until pressure drops to 1540-1550 psi.
Using TOOLBOX, attempt to release PB.
If PB does not release, SAHR canister is binding internally. Replace SAHR canister.
If PB does release, SAHR canister is most likely not the problem.
Cut-off valve or Pressure Supply Valve (PSV) sticking
Can only be isolated when occurring, or by substitution.
When problem is occurring, isolate with steps 18 - 20 of procedure.
Sticking valves are typically caused by improper installation of valve (wrong tool or excessive torque, see service manual).
Intermittent failure to apply. (Shaft extends but, intermittently will not retract.) Possible Cause(s):
Cut-off valve or Pressure Supply Valve (PSV) sticking
Can only be isolated when occurring, or by substitution.
When problem is occurring, isolate with steps 18 - 20 of procedure.
Sticking valves are typically caused by improper installation of valve (wrong tool or excessive torque, see service manual).
Intermittent SERVICE PARK BRAKE indicator with normal park brake operation. Possible Cause(s):
Normal Replenishment - Travel sensor indicating need for replenishment.
Normal operation - a software update will prevent this on future vehicles >5/2008.
Intermittent OPEN electrical circuit from travel sensor to ECU.
Attempt to recreate problem by driving on rough surface, or wriggling harness.
Check for corroded or loose connections (travel sensor and 31-pin ECU connector).
Intermittent travel sensor

Figure 3. Chassis Harness Connector to Travel Sensor
